### Grammar of Graphics

.pull-left[

A data visualization tool that follow grammar of graphics
and provides us with different verbs (functions).

<img src="imgs/ggplot2_tidyverse.png" width="60%">

]

.pull-right[

```{r}
library(ggplot2) #<<
```



]



---
#####**ggplot2:**
#####ggplot2 is one of the packages of 'tidyverse' package for data visualization.
##### Loading the tidyverse package loads all the packages including ggplot2.
```{r message=F}
library(tidyverse) #<<

```
##### If we do not want other packages to be loaded, we can simply load ggplot2 package only.
```{r message=F}

library(ggplot2) #<<
```
---

#####**Creating a ggplot:**

#####ggplot() creates a coordinate system that you can add layers to.

#####What is a layer?
![](img/layers.png)
---

.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[Dataset:]

#####Let's have a look at a table available in R called **"cars"**. It has 2 columns: 
- ######1.speed
- ######2.dist

```{r message=FALSE, echo=FALSE}

cars %>%knitr::kable(format = "html") %>%  kable_paper() %>%
  scroll_box(width = "500px", height = "350px")
 
```


]


.panel[.panel-name[Empty layer:]


#####The first layer is an empty graph to which we are going to add additional layers using the symbol: '+'.

.pull-left[
```{r plot-last, fig.show='hide'}

ggplot(cars) #<<

```
   ]

.pull-right[
```{r ref.label = 'plot-last', echo = FALSE, fig.height=5}

```

  ]
]


.panel[.panel-name[Added layer:1]

######In the second layer, we are going to add a scatter plot using the symbol '+'.
.pull-left[
```{r plot-last2, fig.show='hide',}
ggplot(cars)+
  geom_point(aes(x=speed, y=dist)) #<<
```
  ]
.pull-right[
```{r ref.label='plot-last2', echo=FALSE, fig.height=5}

```

  ]
]

.panel[.panel-name[Added layer:2]

#####In the third layer, we are going to add a line plot using the symbol '+'.
.pull-left[
```{r, plot3, fig.show='hide'}
ggplot(cars)+
  geom_point(aes(x=speed, y=dist)) +
  geom_line(aes(x=speed, y=dist)) #<<

```
  ]
.pull-right[
```{r ref.label='plot3', echo=FALSE, fig.height=5}

```

  ]
]


]

#####First syntax is always going to be :

##### **ggplot**(data= **____**).

#####Here, you are going to mention the name of the table/dataset which you are going to use for data visualization.
]

.panel[.panel-name[Dataset:]

#####cars:


```{r message=FALSE, echo=FALSE}

cars %>%knitr::kable(format = "html") %>%  kable_paper() %>%
  scroll_box(width = "500px", height = "350px")
 
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[Code:Step1]

```{r, fig.show='hide'}
ggplot(data= cars) #<<

```

  ]

---
.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[Aesthetic mapping]

#####Aesthetic mapping:

- #####An aesthetic is a visual property of the objects in your plot. Aesthetics include things like the size, the shape, or the color of your points.
- #####For a particular layer, the components of 'X' and "Y"-axis are defined in aesthetics. Similarly, the properties such as color of the plot, size and shape of the points are also defined in aesthetics.



]

.panel[.panel-name[Example:]

```{r echo=FALSE}
ggplot(cars, aes(speed, dist))+geom_point(size=5, color="blue")
```

]

]

---

#####**Geometric objects**:

--

- #####A geom is the geometrical object that a plot uses to represent data.

--

- ##### geom_point is the geometrical object that plots scatter plot to represent data.

--

#####Geometric objects displayed on the plot:

.font80[
| Type | Function |
|:----:|:--------:|
| Point | `geom_point()` |
| Line | `geom_line()` |
| Bar | `geom_bar()`, `geom_col()` |
| Histogram | `geom_histogram()` |
| Regression | `geom_smooth()` |
| Boxplot | `geom_boxplot()` |
| Text | `geom_text()` |
| Vert./Horiz. Line | `geom_{vh}line()` |
| Count | `geom_count()` |
| Density | `geom_density()` |
]

---
#####We can add other geometrics(geoms) i.e. line_plot and regression_line in addition to the scatter plot.
#####Point to remember: '+' sign should be placed in the same line where the previous layer ends.

.pull_left[

##### **Incorrect way**
```{r  eval=FALSE}
ggplot(data = typ)
+geom_point(mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating)) #<<
+geom_line(mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating))  #<<
```
]
.pull_right[
##### **Correct way**
```{r message=FALSE, eval=FALSE}
ggplot(data = typ)+                   #<<
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating))+  #<<
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating))+
  geom_smooth(mapping=aes(x=Position, y=Rating))
```

]

#####**Apply aesthetics globally**:


.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[Code:]

```{r eval=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
ggplot(data = typ)+                   
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating))+ #<<  
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating)) + #<<
  geom_smooth(mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating)) #<<
```


- #####We can see that the same aesthetics are being used in all of the geoms.


- #####If we supply those aesthetics to **ggplot()** in the beginning, it is applied globally.

```{r eval=FALSE}
ggplot(data = typ, mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating))+                   #<<
  geom_point()+  
  geom_line()+
  geom_smooth()
```

]

.panel[.panel-name[Apply aesthetic for each geom:]

.pull-left[

```{r m1, fig.show='hide',message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}

ggplot(data = typ)+                   
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating))+ #<<  
  geom_line(mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating)) + #<<
  geom_smooth(mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating)) #<<
```

]
.pull-right[

```{r, ref.label="m1", echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE, fig.height=5}


```

]


  ]

.pull-left[

```{r m2, fig.show='hide',message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
ggplot(data = typ, mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating))+                   #<<
  geom_point()+
```

.panelset[


.panel[.panel-name[Other properties: Code]
#####In addition to global aesthetics, we can apply individual aesthetics to their own geoms.

```{r message=FALSE, eval=FALSE}
ggplot(data = typ, mapping = aes(x=Col1, y=Col2))+                   #<<
  geom_point(color='Red')+  #makes the points red
  geom_line(size=0.02)+ #reduces the width of line plot
  geom_smooth(se=F) #removes ribbon around smooth line     
```




]

.panel[.panel-name[Other properties: Plot]

```{r message=FALSE, fig.retina=5, echo=FALSE}
ggplot(data = typ, mapping = aes(x=Position, y=Rating))+                   #<<
  geom_point(color='Red')+  #makes the points red
  geom_line(size=0.02)+ #reduces the width of line plot
  geom_smooth(se=F) #removes ribbon around smooth line     
```




]


]

#####Plotting a smooth line: It has it's own mapping. There is no shape of a point in line. Hence it ignores the parameter 'shape' with a warning.
.pull-left[

# Perform task B: [Task 6 - Task 7]
---
#####Statistical transformation:
.panelset[


.panel[.panel-name[Overview:]
- #####The algorithm used to calculate new values for a graph is called a stat, short for statistical transformation. 

- #####In other graphs such as scatter plot, line plot, smooth-line,  new values are not computed.

- #####In graphs like bar plot, box plots, histograms etc, new values are computed such as counts, proportions, summary etc.
  
]

.panel[.panel-name[Dataset]
##### **diamonds**

```{r message=FALSE, echo=FALSE}

diamonds[1:30, ] %>%knitr::kable(format = "html") %>%  kable_paper() %>%
  scroll_box(width = "500px", height = "350px")
 
```
]

.panel[.panel-name[Process]
![](img/bar1.PNG)
]

]
---

#####Statistical transformation:
.panelset[



.panel[.panel-name[Dataset]
##### **diamonds**

```{r message=FALSE, echo=FALSE}

diamonds[1:30, ] %>%knitr::kable(format = "html") %>%  kable_paper() %>%
  scroll_box(width = "500px", height = "350px")
 
```
]

.panel[.panel-name[Bar plot: ]

.pull-left[
```{r ggplot_bar1, fig.show='hide', message=FALSE}
ggplot(data = diamonds)+
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x=cut)) #<<

#Same code can be written as:
#ggplot(data = diamonds)+geom_bar(mapping = aes(x=cut), stat="count")
```

- #####The 'count' variable is computed and mapped to Y-axis.

]
.pull-right[
```{r ref.label="ggplot_bar1", echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.height=5}
```
]

]

##### Attributes in bar graph(geom_bar):
.panelset[

.panel[.panel-name[Positions:]

##### There are few position adjustments in bar graphs: stack, dodge, identity and fill:
- ##### **stack:** The objects are stacked one on top of the other.
- ##### **dodge:** The objects are placed adjacent to each other.
- ##### **identity:** The objects are placed exactly where it falls on the graph.
- ##### **fill:** works like stacking, but makes each set of stacked bars the same height. This makes it easier to compare proportions across groups.




]


.panel[.panel-name[Dataset]
##### **diamonds**

```{r message=FALSE, echo=FALSE}

diamonds[1:30,] %>%knitr::kable(format = "html") %>%  kable_paper() %>%
  scroll_box(width = "500px", height = "350px")
 
```
]

.panel[.panel-name[Position adjustments]

##### By default, the position is "stack" i.e the fills are stacked one on top of other and the thickness is based on their counts.



.pull-left[
```{r ggplot_bar9, fig.show='hide', message=FALSE}
ggplot(data = diamonds)+
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x=cut, fill=clarity)) #<<
```
]
.pull-right[
```{r ref.label="ggplot_bar9", echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.height=5}

```
]
]

.panel[.panel-name[Plot]

```{r ref.label="ggplot_bar9", echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.height=6, fig.width=10, fig.retina=5}

```
]
]

.panel[.panel-name[3:Identity]

##### **Position:Identity**
##### The objects are placed exactly where it falls on the graph. However, it has a disadvantage.
#####Notice that the fill of "Y" is masked by that of "Z". Hence we need to use opacity(alpha) to notice the actual fill.



.pull-left[
```{r ggplot_bar11, fig.show='hide', message=FALSE}

  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x=col1, fill=col2),
```

```{r ggplot_bar12,message=FALSE,echo=FALSE, fig.retina=5}
ggplot(data = df_bar1)+
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x=col1, fill=col2), position = "identity")+scale_fill_manual(values=c("X"="#e43a39", "Y"="#90ee90", "Z"="#92b7fe"))  #<<
```
